title: Mathew Knowles will 'be fine' after removing three lymph nodes
text:
Mathew has shared his experience of breast cancer (Picture: GMA)

Tina Knowles assures fans that he ex-husband Mathew Knowles will ‘be fine’ after he was diagnosed with breast cancer.

Beyonce’s father, 67, revealed he is battling male breast cancer on the first day of Breast Cancer Awareness month last week during his interview on Good Morning America.

Speaking to Entertainment Tonight, Tina said: ‘Well, you know, thank God he got it very early on. He is going to be fine.’

The former Destiny’s Child manager had three lymph nodes removed and is currently cancer free.

His daughters Beyonce and Solange were also tested after he found out he carried the BRCA2 gene but they thankfully haven’t inherited it.

‘I’m grateful to be cancer free. They found this early and they took out three lymph nodes. I’m good. I’m very fortunate. Early detection, that’s the key,’ Mathew said of his cancer.

Mathew feels breast cancer should be called chest cancer as it may encourage men to check themselves.

Tina and Mathew divorced in 2011 (Picture: George Pimentel/WireImage)

He is also planning to have his ‘other breast removed next year as a precaution.’

‘I’m looking about January time to have the other breast removed just being proactive and reducing the risk,’ the record executive said.

Speaking to TMZ on Thursday, he added that the gene runs in his family and that grandmother’s sister, his aunt, and his aunt’s two daughters all died of breast cancer.

‘Breast cancer has been prevalent in my family,’ he said.

‘My mother’s sister died of breast cancer, my mother’s sister’s two and only daughters died of breast cancer and my sister-in-law died in March of breast cancer with three kids – a nine, 11- and a 15-year-old – and my mother-in-law had breast cancer.

‘So breast cancer has been all around me. My wife’s mother has breast cancer, too.’

Mathew urged men, in particular black men, who are at higher risk of breast cancer, to be aware of the disease and to get checked for early detection.
